Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Investigating the production of stress-induced proteins following nitrite exposure in the commonly farmed shrimp Litopenaeus vannamei
Award.AbstractNarration:
Farmed shrimp comprises a significant portion of global food production, and most of shrimp production comes from Pacific countries such as Taiwan. Aquaculture facilities commonly stock shrimp in unnaturally high densities and produce excessive organic wastes. Shrimp excrete ammonia waste, which is converted to nitrite by microbes. Nitrite accumulates inside the shrimp, causing damage to proteins and cells. In many animals, a common response to stress is the production of a class of proteins called heat shock proteins (HSP). These proteins preserve the shape and function of damaged proteins. However, little is understood about the role of HSPs in aquacultured shrimp. This study aims to quantify the production of HSPs in several shrimp tissues following nitrite stress exposures. This study will be conducted in Taiwan in collaboration with Dr. Cheng-Hao Tang (Institute of Marine Biotechnology, National Dong Hwa University), an expert in stress responses of aquacultured animals. Understanding how HSPs alleviate stress in shrimp will elucidate the effects that aquaculture conditions have on commercially important organisms and their surrounding environments.

Nitrite is an important stressor because it is a common byproduct of microbial metabolism in marine systems, and also a reactive oxidative species. In aquaculture ponds, nitrite can reach an excess of 20 mg mL-1, easily entering the shrimp's system through the gills. This study will quantify production of four different HSP mRNA transcripts and proteins using quantitative PCR and Western Blots. Quantification of HSP transcripts and proteins will be done in the gills and the hepatopancreas where enzymes are produced. Nitrite is one of many stressors that may induce HSP production, and this work will further the framework for examining diverse stress responses using HSPs. The NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the National Science Council of Taiwan.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Just as population growth has led to advance agricultural development, our continued growth and depletion of natural ocean resources is making the aquaculture of seafood increasingly important. The Pacific whiteleg shrimp is currently the dominant shrimp species grown for food globally. However, the high amounts of organic matter put into feeding and growing these shrimp often create imbalances in microbial communities, causing an over-production of nitrite. Nitrite enters the shrimps’ bodies through the gills, accumulating in high amounts within their hemolymph. In high amounts, nitrite causes proteins to change shape and lose their function. These damaged proteins also begin to aggregate and can lead to cell death. Animals have a natural ability to preserve protein quality by either re-folding or destroying damaged proteins. This study examined the Pacific whiteleg shrimp’s ability to preserve protein integrity following nitrite exposure by measuring expression of protein re-folding genes (heat shock protein 70, heat shock cognate 70, and heat shock factor 1) as well as a protein destroying gene (ubiquitin). We studied the expression of these genes in three tissues: the gills where nitrite first enters, the hemocytes which flow freely through the hemolymph, and the hepatopancreas where many important enzymes are produced. By studying these genes, we hoped to elucidate the extent to which a commercially important aquaculture species adapts to or succumbs to nitrite stress.

 

Through the funding and support of the NSF’s EAPSI program, I was able to collaborate with Dr. Cheng-Hao Tang, an aquaculture stress-response scientist in Taiwan. Taiwan is a major player in the global production of shrimp and other important seafood species. Together we were able to develop primers to measure gene expression, and to measure these gene responses in shrimp exposed to nitrite stress. We found that different tissues had different responses to nitrite, which in turn may provide clues to how the organism as a whole responds to this chemical. These genes may also have different roles in overall stress responses at the molecular level. The work is being continued by graduate students in Taiwan to further examine the effects of nitrite at different salinities on shrimp. The opportunity to form new collaborations in a country with a thriving aquaculture and seafood industry was invaluable, and the results provide clues to next steps to take in this research in terms of tissues to target and environmental factors to consider in nitrite stress response.
